fields.title: Sacramento State’s Low Impact Development Tour
fields.description: Welcome to Sacramento State and to the stormwater Low Impact Development (LID) tour.  The tour is a guided walk past 7 stormwater management facilities, called Best Management Practices (BMPs), plus the stormwater discharge near the Guy West Bridge.  Although you may think they’re just planters, these BMPs are carefully designed to capture runoff and remove pollutants.  Take the tour to learn more.

fields.title: Thank you!
fields.description: Thank you for taking this survey!

fields.title: We appreciate your feedback!
fields.description: Thank you for taking the time to answer a few questions!

fields.title: About The Project
fields.description:
In 2015, Sacramento State’s Office of Water Programs (OWP) and Facilities Management teamed with the City of Sacramento to install new stormwater management devices on campus.  Major funding was obtained through a Proposition 84 grant from the State Water Resources Control Board.  The City of Sacramento administered the grant. The Office of Water Programs provided technical oversight and Facilities Management provided construction management services. Facilities design and construction were performed by outside contractors, some of whom are listed below.

These facilities, also called Best Management Practices (BMPs), are intended to reduce stormwater impacts to the American and Sacramento Rivers. Stormwater runoff from urban development is one of the leading contributors of water quality degradation.  By fitting seamlessly into the built environment and maximizing opportunities to infiltrate runoff and reduce discharges to the rivers, these BMPs follow a design philosophy known as Low Impact Development (LID).

One purpose of this project is to provide opportunities for the public and stormwater professionals to see examples of how LID BMPs can be retrofitted to existing parking lots and streets.  Click here  to read about design and construction challenges common to all the BMP installations.  Take the tour to see them.

All of the BMPs in this project were designed according to the 2015 Sacramento Stormwater Quality Partnership’s Stormwater Quality Design Manual.  Detailed descriptions, drawings, specifications, and lessons learned can be found on our website at http://www.owp.csus.edu/csus-lid/.

fields.title: Cooperating Partners
fields.description:

fields.title: State Funding Disclaimer
fields.description: Funding for this project has been provided in full or in part through an agreement with the California State Water Resources Control Board.

fields.title: Lot 7 Bioretention Planter
fields.simple_directions: Walk to the south side parking lot 7 planter.
fields.description: This is one of several bioretention planters in Parking Lot 7.  Be careful if you are visiting during school hours; the parking lot can be very active.

fields.title: Lot 7 Infiltrating Bioswale
fields.simple_directions: Move to the south side of campus, parking lot 7.
fields.description: The goal of this installation was to change a little-noticed strip of grass into a working stormwater BMP.

fields.title: Lot 10 Bioretention Planter
fields.simple_directions: Move to the Lot 10 student parking lot on the south side of Campus.
fields.description: This is one of two bioretention planters in Parking Lot 10.  Be careful if you are visiting during school hours; the parking lot can be very active.

fields.title: Library Green Rain Garden and Porous Pavement
fields.simple_directions: Follow signs to the Campus Library.
fields.description: There are two Library Green rain gardens – one in the lawn and one in the redwood grove with a path made from porous concrete pavement.

fields.title: Calaveras Hall Bioretention Planter and Porous Pavement
fields.simple_directions: Move around to the North Side of Calaveras Hall.
fields.description: This is a combination of three BMPs:  (1) downspout disconnection, (2) a bioretention planter, and (3) porous concrete pavement.

fields.title: Calaveras Hall Biofilter
fields.simple_directions: Walk to the west side of Calaveras Hall.
fields.description: This is a combination of two BMPs:  (1) downspout disconnection followed by a (2) biofilter.

fields.title: College Town Drive Rain Gardens
fields.simple_directions: Walk over to College Town Drive.
fields.description: The College Town Dr. rain gardens are designed to be an extremely low cost BMP to replace an informal buffer strip between a bike path and the street.

fields.title: Jed Smith Green Street
fields.simple_directions: Head toward the Jed Smith Green Street.
fields.description: Jed Smith Drive has been converted to a “green street” with porous pavement parking lanes and streetside rain gardens.

fields.title: Guy West Bridge Outfall
fields.simple_directions: Head toward the Guy West Bridge.
fields.description: Crossing the American River between Sacramento State and the Campus Commons neighborhood, the Guy West Bridge is a popular biking and walking destination.

fields.title: Porous Pavement
fields.description: Click here for more details on porous concrete pavement.

fields.title: Bioretention Planter
fields.description: Click here for more details on bioretention planters.

fields.title: Library Green Garden
fields.description: A cross-section of the Library Green Rain Garden and the porous pavement path that runs alongside it.

fields.title: Porous Pavement Parking Lane
fields.description:
A photo of the development of the Jed Smith Green Street site. Notice that the porous pavement is lined, so that the infiltrating water doesn't erode the foundation of the surrounding pavement. 

After this site was opened, campus delivery services notified the campus that the road was dangerously narrow now that cars were parking on either side of the road. The decision was made to remove parking on one side in order to allow for more spacing. As such, the East side of Jed Smith no longer accommodates parking.

fields.title: Existing Drainage
fields.description: Existing drainage could not be removed, as the system is still utilized (though in a lesser capacity). Enginers needed to plan ahead, and build around the existing system.

fields.title: Machinery
fields.description: Due to the weight of heavy machinery, and the role it can play in compacting underlying soils, it was requested that crews not such machinery. The message wasn't always passed down to those who were actually doing the work.

fields.title: Mislabeled Drawings
fields.description: Sometimes during excavation of a site, you find that previous contractors have mislabeled their drawings, which can lead to the unearthing of drainage pipes that are declared to be more than twenty feet away.

fields.title: Pathway
fields.description: Here, a backhoe carves out what would become the porous pavement pathway that leads through the Library Green.

fields.title: Gutter Cutouts
fields.description: Gutter Cutouts allow water that would normally have either been trapped on the road or funneled into the drainage system to instead run off of the road, and flow into the rain gardens that line College Town Drive.

fields.title: Curbside Cutouts
fields.description: Curbside cutouts allow water that would normally have been directed into the existing drainage system to instead drain into the newly installed bioretention planters. Doing so prevents hundreds, if not thousands, of gallons of water from being pumped into the American River.

fields.title: Rain Garden
fields.description: The Calaveras Hall Rain garden is specially designed, with every effort made to lead the water far away from the building's foundation

fields.title: Previous Landscaping
fields.description: Before the bioswale, this location was covered in grass, which is not drough-tolerant, and so had turned brown. The plants in his bioswale are drought and inundation tolerant, meaning they can go for extended periods of time without watering, as well as be submerged for many days without harm to the plants

fields.title: Polluted Water
fields.description: The photo above shows why the university is cleaning up its stormwater.  The bottle on the left is a sample of American River water collected just upstream of the bridge.  The bottle on the right contains stormwater runoff from the campus.  Typical city runoff looks about the same.

fields.title: Guy West Construction
fields.description: Guy West Bridge during construction.

fields.title: Guy West
fields.description: Guy West, circa 1958

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	This bioretention planter retains and treats stormwater from Parking Lot 7.

•	Stormwater is treated as it passed through layers of mulch, top soil, and compost-amended soil (see diagram below).

•	In small storms the filtered water infiltrates into the soil, but in larger storms, it accumulates in a gravel layer (underdrain) beneath the filter and is piped to the concrete drain inlet (the box with a metal grate). In a very large storm the planter would fill up and overflow into concrete drain inlet. 

•	Water entering the drain inlet at this site flows to the campus drainage system and is pumped into the American River near the Guy West Bridge (see later stop on the tour). 

•	Existing parking lot facilities placed big constraints on designers:

o	Locate planters around existing drain inlets to avoid re-grading the parking lots. 

o	Avoid placing planters in the travel lanes for cars.

o	Try to avoid building over underground utilities and around lights that would have to be replaced.  Avoid replacing trees where possible.

o	Minimize the number of parking stalls lost (a very important design goal).

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	Originally this was a narrow strip of lawn. To create the bioswale, the grass and underlying soil were removed and replaced with a permeable soil/compost mix (see diagram below).  The surface of the bioswale was purposely set below the street grade to form a shallow depression that collects runoff.  To get the water from the street to the bioswale, the existing curb was cut in several places.

•	The primary treatment mechanism is infiltration of small storms into the ground.  In larger storms, the swale will fill up and overflow into a new drain inlet (the concrete box) that is connected to the campus drainage system.  Before this happens though, the water will pond up, which encourages particulate pollutants to settle out.  This is a secondary treatment mechanism.

•	Water entering the drain inlet at this site flows to the campus drainage system and is pumped into the American River near the Guy West Bridge (see later stop on the tour).

•	Siting the bioswale here avoided the need to re-grade the street, which minimized costs.  Using simple curb cuts instead of rain inlets is another cost-saving feature.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	This bioretention planter is one of two that retain and treat stormwater from Parking Lot 10.

•	Stormwater is treated as it passed through layers of top soil, and compost-amended soil (see diagram below).

•	In small storms the filtered water infiltrates into the soil, but in larger storms, it accumulates in a gravel layer (underdrain) beneath the filter and is piped to the concrete drain inlet (the box with a metal grate). In a very large storm the planter would fill up and overflow into concrete drain inlet. 

•	Water from the drain inlets flows to the drainage ditch on the north edge of the parking lot and eventually is pumped into the American River off campus.

•	Existing parking lot facilities placed big constraints on designers:

o	Locate planters around existing drain inlets to avoid re-grading the parking lots. 

o	Avoid placing planters in the travel lanes for cars.

o	Try to avoid building over underground utilities and around lights that would have to be replaced.  Avoid replacing trees where possible.

o	Minimize the number of parking stalls lost (a very important design goal).

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	These two rain gardens accept water from the existing, less pervious grass lawn and from local impervious walkways.  

•	Rain gardens are designed to provide better infiltration than grass alone. These rain gardens are not lined so that runoff infiltrates into the native soils below (see diagram below).  In large storms water overflows into the existing drainage system and is piped to the American River.  To minimize costs, the gardens were built around existing drain inlets.  

•	Near the redwood trees, a porous concrete pavement walkway was installed to replace the existing decomposed granite path.  Water that passes through the porous concrete is stored in an underlying gravel layer and infiltrates into the soil between storms. 

•	Have a seat on the rocks and take a minute to enjoy this nice spot.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	Before this project, the building downspouts were connected directly to the campus storm drain system.  Runoff from the roof was sent directly to the American River with no treatment.

•	For this BMP, the downspouts were cut and the runoff was channeled away from the building in concrete valley gutters to a new bioretention planter built on the site of an old lawn.  

•	Porous concrete pavement was installed adjacent to the rain garden to fill the old lawn area that was not needed for the planter.  Water passing through the pavement infiltrates into the soil.  

•	In small storms the water sent to the bioetention planter is filtered through the media and  infiltrates into the soil  In larger storms, it accumulates in a gravel layer (underdrain) beneath the filter and is piped to the concrete drain inlet (the box with a metal grate).  In a very large storm the planter would fill up and overflow into concrete drain inlet (see diagram below). 

•	Water entering the drain inlet at this site flows to the campus drainage system and is pumped into the American River near the Guy West Bridge (see later stop on the tour).

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	Before this project, the building downspouts were connected directly to the campus storm drain system.  Runoff from the roof was sent directly to the American River with no treatment.

•	For this BMP, the downspouts were cut and the runoff was channeled away from the building in concrete valley gutters to a new concrete-lined biofilter.

•	The filter material is housed in a fully lined concrete casing because of its proximity to the building (see diagram below).  Allowing runoff to infiltrate too close to a building can have adverse impacts on the building’s foundation.  

•	After filtration through a mix of topsoil and compost, the runoff is directed back to the drainage system that was once directly connected to the roof.  The difference, of course, is that now the water is cleaner.  In large storms, a new drain inlet connected to the campus drainage system captures overflows. 

•	To build the filter, a line of juniper bushes had to be removed, but they have been replaced by new plantings of native and/or drought-tolerant vegetation in and around the biofilter.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	Along College Town Dr. four unlined rain gardens like this one were installed in the grass strip.  The gardens capture runoff and infiltrate it into the ground.    

•	The garden was built by simply excavating a small area of existing lawn and underlying soils, and replacing them with a soil/compost mix (see diagram below).  This mix is more permeable than the lawn it replaced. The surface of the mix was purposely set below the street grade to form a shallow depression.  Two cuts were made in the existing curbs along the road to allow runoff to enter the garden.  If the runoff flow is larger than the garden’s infiltration capacity, the garden fills up, which causes water in the street to bypass the curb cuts and flow to the existing drain inlet.

•	Because it does not require any pipes or channeling, this was an inexpensive BMP.  Actual costs at any particular site depend on local conditions, especially underground facilities.  At this site, the electrical wire for the street lamps had to be moved out from under the basins.

•	How much water infiltrates depends on both the surface material and the permeability of the underlying soil.  Along College Town Dr. the existing soil permeability varies and some rain gardens are infiltrating more than others.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	On the east side of the street, an existing lawn was replaced with a 3-cell rain garden.  On the west side, angled street parking was removed to allow construction of rain gardens and a new sidewalk.  Parallel parking lanes with porous concrete pavement were installed on both sides of the street.  

•	The rain gardens and porous pavement (see diagrams below) collect runoff and infiltrate it into the native soil.  In large storms, runoff that cannot be taken up by the soil overflows into the campus drain system and is conveyed to the American River.   

•	The eastern rain garden is made up of three interconnected cells to preserve the roots of the existing trees.  Tree canopy is valuable for reducing urban heat exchange and encouraging pedestrian and bicycle use.  The existing heritage trees and new gardens are designed to aesthetically complement each other.  Runoff for this eastern garden comes from the parking lot around the police building. 

•	The rain garden on the west side receives runoff from the parking lot between Jed Smith Dr. and Parking Structure 3.  The existing storm drains were capped to direct the runoff to the rain garden.  The northern portion of the lot drains into a cobble trench and the runoff flows underground to the rain garden.  

•	The porous concrete pavement in the street is 6 inches deep on top of a 12 inch gravel base.  You can literally pour water on it from a bucket (click here to see video).  

•	Retrofitting an existing street involved several design challenges:

o	To avoid impacting the roots of existing trees the rain garden on the west side was divided into three parts, connected with underground piping that juts diagonally around the trees.  (Look for shiny metal covers on the west side of the sidewalk between the rain garden cells.)

o	To minimize the loss of angled parking stalls, parallel parking was placed in the street and an adjacent off-street parking lot was expanded.

o	To reduce the total impervious area and accommodate the parallel parking, 11-foot drive aisles were provided.  Delivery truck and bus drivers, however, have expressed safety concerns and the parallel parking on the east side of the street has been closed while this issue is being addressed.

fields.title: Site Features
fields.description:
•	At this location, stormwater runoff captured from the eastern side of campus is pumped through the levee and into the American River.  If you walk out onto the bridge to the first tower and look down, you will see the discharge pipes sticking out of the ground.  The concrete pavement down the face of the levees prevents erosion when the pumps are operating.  To see a short video of the discharge, click here. 

•	The goal of water quality regulation is to protect the beneficial uses of the river.  Look around.  You will (or might) see several beneficial uses:

o	Municipal water supply (the tower upstream is the water intake for the Fairbairn water treatment plant)

o	Boating, fishing, and swimming

o	Fish habitat, migration and spawning (at the right time of year you can see salmon swimming upstream)

•	The photo below shows why the university is cleaning up its stormwater.  The bottle on the left is a sample of American River water collected just upstream of the bridge.  The bottle on the right contains stormwater runoff from the campus.  Typical city runoff looks about the same.

fields.title: About The Bridge
fields.description:
The Guy West Bridge is named after first president of Sacramento State.  Dr. West, whose background was educational psychology, headed the university for 18 years, from when it opened in 1947 with 253 students in rented quarters at Sacramento City College to 1965 when enrollment topped 10,000 at the current site.  

The bridge was designed by Ted D'Amico of the Spink Corporation, a local engineering firm and cost $636,000.  A suspension style bridge was chosen so that the towers could be built on land rather than in the water.  At 1147 feet long, it was the longest pedestrian suspension bridge in the U.S. at the time of its opening in 1967.  Its general design and color, International Orange, are designed to be reminiscent of the Golden Gate Bridge.
